title: 5 art-related things that sparked something in me this week
text:
A wonky-lined church in Finist√®re, Brittany, France, June 2025.
Link to the post on my substack

These past weeks, I‚Äôve been delving into the work of Berthe Morisot. There was a major exhibition of her paintings in 2019 at the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay. The inaugural lecture tells so many great stories about this artist. For instance, we usually associate Berthe Morisot with themes such as maternity. She does, indeed, paint her daughter Julie often ‚Äî and I love how we can see Julie growing up from painting to painting. But the curator of the exhibition aptly shows that Morisot, for example, paints Julie in the arms of her nanny, so in a way she‚Äôs painting a woman at work while she herself is at work. The curator also discusses what women could draw at the time. It‚Äôs often said that Berthe mainly painted scenes from private life ‚Äî her husband posed for her, but he was very jittery about it sometimes. Yet there were not so many opportunities for women at that time to paint directly in the street.
Nevertheless, when she goes to England, there are a few outdoor paintings. On that note, I love how she describes the process of painting outside. We usually romanticize it a lot, but it is very refreshing to see a painter like Berthe Morisot write about trying to do oil painting in a field, only for all the children from the town to follow her, create mayhem, and get her scolded for the mess.She is not a big fan of bad weather or the curiosity of passersby. So she decides to paint from her window to shield herself from those inconveniences. But the passersby are too quick and impossible to capture. She writes to her sister: ‚ÄúFrom my window, it‚Äôs very pretty to look at, but very ugly to paint.‚Äù She also tries to paint from a boat: ‚ÄúBy boat, it‚Äôs a different story, everything is rocking, it‚Äôs a hellish lapping sound; you have the sun, the wind‚Ä¶‚Äù Speaking of passersby being too quick to capture in painting, I came across a funny anecdote: when Renoir was trying to draw people while working on Le Pont Neuf, he would send his younger brother Edmond to talk to them, in order to stall them. He would ask for directions or the time ‚Äî anything really ‚Äî just to make them stop and keep still for a few seconds.

On that note, I read The Complete Urban Sketching Companion a while ago, and I vividly remember a piece of advice from it: if you can‚Äôt fully draw one passerby, you can identify generic gestures. ‚ÄúThousands of runners zoom by ‚Äî all runners make more or less the same moves, so it‚Äôs like sketching the same person passing by again and again. In these cases, you can make composites of several runners into one.‚Äù

The Urban Sketching Handbook: 101 Sketching Tips is also a gold mine for urban sketchers. My favourite piece of advice has to be: ‚ÄúEmbrace the wonkiness of your line! Tilt it, curve it.‚Äù (Wonkiness = the fact of not being straight.) I love a good old wonky line ‚Äî I don‚Äôt like any drawing of mine where my lines are too straight. The book includes very practical and specific tips such as: ‚ÄúBlacken small window panes for pop.‚Äù ‚ÄúTry to keep your hatch marks fairly consistent.‚Äù But it also offers advice on composition. For example, you can take a picture of what you see, then look at the photo and notice what immediately pops out to your eyes. Here are a few of my other favourites: - ‚ÄúA viewer needs to feel like they can literally walk into the sketch.‚Äù - ‚ÄúAngling the ground and horizon on your page creates an imbalance that pushes your eye around the page.‚Äù - ‚ÄúTo show something is up high, put it high on the page.‚Äù - ‚ÄúMultiple views tell many aspects of a story.‚Äù - ‚ÄúMultiple images in a linear sequence indicate the passage of time.‚Äù(Example: Suhita Shirodkar, Election Day 2‚Äì3 p.m. drawing.)

This book introduced me to the work of Malaysian sketcher KK, with the idea that a composition can have no particular focal point but simply let the eye wander across the page. One interesting method KK uses is to start on one page and then add more pages as you ‚Äúgrow your sketch.‚Äù Drawing becomes a kind of mushroom process, colonizing your sketchbooks.

title: 5 art-related things that sparked something in me this week
text:
A page from my own sketchbook, May 2025, Lyon, France
Link to the post on my substack

Why are we so fascinated by notebook flipthroughs? Like some of you, I‚Äôm an absolute fan of artistic notebook flipthrough videos : I‚Äôll watch almost any kind - off the top of my head, Eleanor Doughty‚Äôs are favorites, for instance one, or that one. The New Yorker once called this passion a ‚Äúdelightful form of snooping‚Äù, while writing about the Sketchbook Project. (This giant project began by giving blank Moleskines to people for a small fee and archiving whatever came back. In the end, there were thousands of notebooks from all sorts of people, that you could go and browse at the Brooklyn Art Library - the archives are now in transit to several museums.) Here, I‚Äôm not talking about why having a sketchbook matters. I‚Äôm talking about why I love watching a video of the pages turning in a finished sketchbook. For me, it is energizing in the sense that you see individual pieces that form the flow of artistic life (a drawing of a building, or your little nephew‚Äôs feet) into a whole, an enclosed project that has a beginning, a middle, and an end. And as in all well-written stories, what makes a sketchbook flipthrough memorable is that there is variety: the good, the bad, and the ugly. Self-editing your own sketchbook too much might even do you a disservice. On that note, my mum used to say that the best part of my watercolor paintings was the blank paper next to the actual painting where I tested my colours. There‚Äôs beauty in seeing a sketchbook through to the end; a sense of awe at the artist‚Äôs consistency. September is a month of beginnings - usually a month when you start a sketchbook with a whole new academic year ahead of you (whether you‚Äôre a student or not), the crisp blank paper full of promises. Now, why not take an old sketchbook, finish it, and flip through it? Because, why the heck not.
Exhibition: I went to David Hockney‚Äôs exhibition (Hockney 25) in Paris two weeks ago ‚Äî I made a video of my favourite paintings ‚Äî and saw multiple echoes of van Gogh‚Äôs work. There was a room in the exhibition dedicated to Hockney‚Äôs work on moons (the moon room). Funnily enough, just as van Gogh tried to paint at night (arguing that even if he couldn‚Äôt see the colors on his palette, he could see the real scene in front of him), David Hockney resolved the quandary of painting outdoors at night by using the inherent lighting of the iPad.
Learning about how we make statues: A little while ago, I went drawing at the Mus√©e Bourdelle in Paris with a friend. It has a garden full of sculptures made by Bourdelle, where you can sketch under the trees and walk along the green path that takes you from one gigantic statue to the next. I ended up watching a video on the process of making a bronze statue ‚Äî I had no idea it was this complex! I couldn‚Äôt find the video shown at the museum, but the Rodin Museum has a detailed description online.
I read the children‚Äôs book Les Vermeilles by Camille Jourdy. It is an enchanting tale about a girl who loses herself in the forest and meets all sorts of strange animals and people (for instance, the tiny queen and king on minuscule horses), echoing Spirited Away. The depiction of the forest, full of dots, reminded me of David Hockney‚Äôs paintings of Normandy although the color palettes are different: Hockney uses more vibrant greens, while Camille Jourdy works with pastel greens.
I re-read Austin Kleon‚Äôs Keep Going this week. I love this author ‚Äî he is one of the best ‚Äúartistic self-help‚Äù authors I know, and I mean that in the best possible way. Brace yourself for my favourite quotes: ‚ÄúLeonardo da Vinci made ‚Äòto-learn‚Äô lists. He‚Äôd get up in the morning and write down everything he wanted to learn that day.‚Äù I‚Äôd take that any day over the endless to-do list at the start of the school year. The second one is about creative practice and money: ‚ÄúThe minute anybody shows any talent for anything we suggest they turn it into a profession. [‚Ä¶] We used to have hobbies; now we have ‚Äòside hustles‚Äô.‚Äù And now, for something completely different: ‚ÄúI ignore every ‚Äò35 under 35‚Äô list published. [‚Ä¶] I only want to read the ‚Äò8 over 80‚Äô list.‚Äù Finally, that last bit is essentially the reason I am making this newsletter in the first place: ‚ÄúIf art begins where we point our attention, a life is made out of paying attention to what we pay attention to.‚Äù

title: 5 art-related things that sparked something in me this week
text:
Link to the post on my substack

I‚Äôve been reading Letters to Theo by Vincent van Gogh.
It is the correspondence Vincent wrote throughout his life to his brother.
The letters are in turn poetic, funny, witty, delightfully weird, and all in all wonderful. For instance, in this 1883 letter, he starts with: I feel what Pa and Ma instinctively think about me (I don‚Äôt say reasonably). There‚Äôs a similar reluctance about taking me into the house as there would be about having a large, shaggy dog in the house. He‚Äôll come into the room with wet paws ‚Äì and then, he‚Äôs so shaggy. He‚Äôll get in everyone‚Äôs way. And he barks so loudly. In short ‚Äì it‚Äôs a dirty animal. I mean, the man was funny.
I visited Auvers-sur-Oise and stopped by the Ch√¢teau d‚ÄôAuvers for the exhibition The Last Journeys of Vincent Van Gogh.
It focuses on his last four years. The audio guide is narrated by Wouter van der Veen ‚Äì who was also invited by Radio France to talk about Vincent and money (he describes himself as a free biographer on the subject). The exhibition starts with Theo‚Äôs success in Paris with his gallery, then moves on to Vincent‚Äôs life in Paris, and then the usual steps: Arles, Saint-R√©my, Auvers-sur-Oise. The exhibition concludes with a short animated film by Fleur de Papier, telling the story of Johanna van Gogh-Bonger. She was Vincent‚Äôs brother Theo‚Äôs wife, widowed at 28 with a baby. She devoted her life to making his art known, in a world of men who considered her, at best, irritating and obsessed with a dead, unknown crazy guy. I instantly adored her.
In an episode on Radio France, Jan Blanc, art historian, talks about how Vincent did not associate painting with pain, as many people depict him, so much as he saw painting as a healing process. In that sense, the paintings with the cut ear are not about that at all, but rather paintings with the bandaged ear.
I saw the animated film Loving Vincent, a 2017 British-Polish production that tells the story of an investigation into the death of Vincent van Gogh through the character of Armand Roulin, son of the postman Roulin, one of Vincent‚Äôs friends. The film alternates between sequences painted entirely by hand in oil, imitating more than 80 of Van Gogh‚Äôs canvases, and black-and-white passages recounting periods or episodes of his life that he did not paint. I watched the making-of video on YouTube: more than 80 oil painters were hired to paint Vincent‚Äôs canvases after the scenes were filmed against a green screen. The character of Armand Roulin must deliver Vincent‚Äôs last letter to Theo and therefore travels to Paris, where he meets P√®re Tanguy, and then to Auvers-sur-Oise, where he seeks out Dr.¬†Gachet. In Paris, he wanders through paintings of the Moulin de la Galette, the vineyards of Montmartre, and the Place Clichy. The filmmakers explain that some of the paintings‚Äô color palettes had to be modified to match the season chosen for the film: summer. The palette was therefore borrowed from other of Vincent‚Äôs paintings of Paris depicting summer.
In the same vein as oil painting, I tested the set of brushes made by Manero Brushes to reproduce this technique on Procreate. He offers a few tutorial videos on YouTube. I focused on several brushes in particular.
Manero‚Äôs tutorials are excellent, but quite fast to follow, so I prefer to do the main steps at the same time as him, then try to make my own painting separately without trying to reproduce the whole detailed process, because I find that I learn better by doing my own. I made an illustration with a van Gogh inspiration (photo from the newsletter). Thousands and thousands of tiny brushstrokes.

title: 5 art-related things that sparked something in me this week
text:
In honor of my parents going to Japan, today‚Äôs list is made up of Japanese art-related things (except the first one).
Link to the post on my substack

I‚Äôve been reading a lot about lists lately. Lists can be forms of art. In the preface to Lists of Note, Shaun Usher, who describes himself as a professional nerd, explains why we absolutely adore lists as human beings. He gives three reasons: ‚Äúlife is chaotic‚Äù; ‚Äúeveryone is a critic‚Äù (ranking things is addictive, I count myself in that category while writing this); and finally ‚Äútime is precious‚Äù (making lists saves us time, so we have more time for hobbies and, of course, to make more lists). The book comprises many lists, some of which are terrifying or hilarious (like the list of temporary golf rules sent to club members while bombs were being dropped on the course in 1940, Richmond, England: ‚Äúduring gunfire or while bombs are falling, players may take cover without penalty for ceasing play‚Äù), some are wittily written (list of rules for not flirting, distributed by the Anti-Flirt Club, an organization of women in the 1920s), and some are surprisingly accurate (a wish list of things to be achieved by science made in 1662 - many of which have since come true). I also remembered stumbling upon a self-help psychology book about lists at the library a few years back. Most were the typical kinds of lists meant to help with life (your classic run-of-the-mill to-do lists), but what I loved were the weirder ones: like someone‚Äôs favorite lost lists. For instance, one person lost a list made in Mexico, in front of La Casa Azul - where Frida Kahlo lived - containing the names of all the cats that had lived there, as told by the gardener (mysteriously lost on a bus). Art comes from all sorts of places - but for me, those places are often recorded in the Notes app on my phone. I wholeheartedly agree with the idea that ‚Äúthe most interesting thing on someone‚Äôs phone is in their notes app,‚Äù as said by Hannah Connolly. In that spirit, go and make a weird list today !
Animation: last month, I had the opportunity to see Little Am√©lie, or the Character of Rain in a small cinema in the village in the Alps where I was staying.
Halfway through the film, I was completely charmed by: the multitude of colorful plants in the garden; Am√©lie‚Äôs discovery of white chocolate; the little radio that the Japanese nanny, Nishio-san, always carries with her to do her gymnastics; the way Am√©lie bottles all the sounds and impressions of the seaside for her nanny in a glass jar; the intricate construction of the lantern for the river ceremony; the making of spinning tops (goma) that make the child dizzy; and the reading of the Book of Monsters (y≈çkai).
The style kept reminding me of something. It was only at the end that I noticed the name Lucr√®ce Andreae, credited for the storyboard. She is an incredibly talented artist, known for the short film P√©p√© le morse (about grief over a grandfather‚Äôs death) and the graphic novel Flipette et V√©n√®re.
There are echoes in color and form across all three pieces: Am√©lie‚Äôs wide eyes as she looks at the garden resemble the child‚Äôs oversized eyes as he stares across the dunes at his grandfather‚Äôs ‚Äúghost‚Äù; the purplish tones of Am√©lie‚Äôs skin underwater mirror V√©n√®re‚Äôs skin color in the graphic novel.
This year, I discovered Tsukimi, a podcast created by Mathilda Motte. I especially focused on the archived episodes that explore the stories and notable features of the traditional Japanese calendar (Ky√ªreki), month by month. There are 72 microseasons in a year. As I publish this post, the current microseason is swallows depart. Last week, wagtails sing was in season, and next week, thunder‚Äôs voice quiets will follow. In September, the podcast invites us to observe: the leaves turning khaki green, dried sunflowers drooping, and the nostalgic feeling of summer‚Äôs end (nagori).
Radio interview: Ryoko Sekiguchi is a talented author and translator. In an old interview, she explains that writing can sometimes be a lonely endeavor. I remember she mentions three poetic ways to ease that weight:1) She would go out and eat at countertops in restaurants - not just any table, not on a patio, but at the old-fashioned, cafeteria-style counter where you‚Äôre never really eating alone. 2) While writing, she would also cook something very slowly, like a stew - the sounds and smells of cooking creating a presence. 3) She would buy lots of flowers to fill her apartment - thanks to all the money she had saved during the pandemic.
Book: Tsubaki Stationery Store, Ito Ogawa. In this book, the main character returns to her hometown to work as a public scribe, in the shop her grandmother left her. The story is seemingly simple, but it‚Äôs filled with beautifully detailed artistic processes. The character always takes the time to create - with her own hands - the most beautiful solution to each request. It‚Äôs funny because, in the book, she mentions feeling guilty when looking at her fountain pens, which she never cleans properly - unlike her grandmother, who always did. And now, this book gives me that exact same feeling whenever I think about my own fountain pen, which I also never clean properly (I know I should).

Thank you for reading this totally free, human-made newsletter that focuses on art-related things I found interesting - and that hopefully you do too.

title: 5 art-related things that sparked something in me this week
text:
A painting of a coffee morning with autumn leaves, September 2025.
Link to the post on my substack

This week I discovered the work of Catel and Bocquet. Together, they have written a great number of books about women - women in the arts, women in politics. Last week, I read two of them. The first one was Kiki de Montparnasse. She was a model for artists in the 1920s. The graphic novel explores her life both as an artist herself and as a muse for artists such as Man Ray, Foujita, Soutine, etc. She was also a singer and a dancer in Paris cabarets, nicknamed ‚Äúqueen of the night.‚Äù The graphic novel shows her exhibiting her own work and painting at times. But it feels as though she couldn‚Äôt care less about the exhibitions - she‚Äôs just happy they pay for her champagne. The end is very touching: she‚Äôs depicted almost like a Fellini heroine or like Madame Rosa in La Vie devant soi by Romain Gary. Bloated and alcoholic, she is nevertheless captured as the dazzling lady from her youth, full of panache and laughter.
The second graphic novel I read this week by Catel and Bocquet was about Alice Guy. She is a forgotten figure in the history of cinema. She started out at Gaumont as a typist and went on to make phonosc√®nes (early sound films). She created the first version of the movie called The Cabbage Patch Fairy. (Side note: I‚Äôve watched it, and let me tell you, the babies do not seem to be having a blast.) The lack of recognition is heartbreaking at times. At one point, the book highlights how she was building her own personal archive on paper because films are volatile things: they come, they go, but never quite stick. In doing so, she became the documentarian of her own work. Thank God for that - because later, she even complained that film historians had attributed many of her films to a man (Henri Gallet)!
The two books reminded me of another graphic novel I read back in the spring: Vivian Maier Claire Obscure by Marzena Sowa and Emilie Plateau. The graphic novel tells the story of Vivian Maier, the photographer who worked as a nanny all her life and died in anonymity. It is shorter than the first two graphic novels mentioned before. It left ample room for curiosity. I had come across her name before - there was an exhibition in Paris some time ago at the Mus√©e du Luxembourg, and the line was so long it nearly wrapped around the entire garden - but I had never looked into her work.
Documentary: Therefore, I watched the documentary Finding Vivian Maier (2013). The film tells the story of how a young man named John Maloof purchased boxes of her negatives at a Chicago auction in 2007. He developed the films and found breathtaking photographs, which he scanned and uploaded to the internet. The images elicited some interest, and from then on, he made it his mission to gather all her belongings and make her work known to the world. Vivian Maier kept everything and documented everything. She made the children she cared for walk for hours in so-called ‚Äúbad neighbourhoods‚Äù so she could take pictures. Her personal archive, which traveled with her from house to house, became so heavy that in one of the homes where she worked, the floor of her room actually collapsed. Interestingly, the documentary also sheds light on darker aspects of her personality.
Book: I started reading the work of R.F. Kuang with Babel back in early summer. I loved it, but I won‚Äôt talk about that one here - instead, I‚Äôll talk about Yellowface. This is a riveting novel. [SPOILER ALERT, proceed at your own risk] It tells the story of June, who is friends with Athena. Athena is Chinese-American and a very successful young author. June attended Yale at the same time but made her debut in the literary world far less spectacularly. Athena abruptly dies in an accident, and June accidentally gets her hands on Athena‚Äôs latest draft, which no one has read. The rest tells itself. The voice of the narrator is incredibly unsympathetic at times, and cynical most of the time, and yet you can‚Äôt stop reading. The novel explores so many contemporary conundrums in today‚Äôs publishing industry that it can make you dizzy at times. It reads like a thriller.

Elle dit que dans les films d‚Äôhorreur, ils sont habituellement signifi√©s par des ombres ou des bruits, pas par des odeurs ! En r√©alit√©, ce n‚Äôest pas tout √† fait vrai.
